comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: Before February 1936. "Mr. J. Dowling, of Rockdale, in a letter to the Editor, says that a beautiful fig tree, which stood in the small garden reserve on the western side of the Central Railway station, has been sawn off at the base. About 12 months ago the branches were lopped, but the foliage eventually regained its former beauty. Now, he says, it has been converted into an eyesore." - DESTRUCTION OF TREE, The Sydney Morning Herald, Friday 14 February 1936, p.4. - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/17332879 "NSWR 190[6?]" - could the garden plantings be to mark the anniversary of the opening of the new railway station in 1906? Perhaps the 25th anniversary in August 1931? [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/5638800941/]

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/47201412@N02] Unfortunatley fig trees have a huge root system which have a habit of destroying roads and paths. Perhaps it was starting to cause such problems at Central Railway. I remember the figs in Manly started to rip up all manner of things some years ago.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Terrific!  Part of The Tree Mystery is solved!  I still find it astounding that they obliterated 4-6 blocks of buildings, roads, cemeteries, sandhills, etc, and kept one tree.  Go FIGure!

comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] You found it, nice one! An 'eyesore' indeed, hmph...
